The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasitic animals that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. To understand the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite, we compared the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the Myxozoa are a sister taxon to the cnidarian parasite Polypodium hydriforme and that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These findings have implications for understanding the origin of parasitism and the evolution of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy to ensure their replication and propagation. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated transcription factors, which is a key step for induction of antiviral genes. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 evades the host antiviral response and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect global food production, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to predict how maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the top four maize-exporting countries. Our results highlight the importance of heat tolerance in maize breeding and the urgency of such efforts. They also underscore the importance of international grain trade in ensuring food security in the face of climate change.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of plant material is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results have implications for the management of large mammal populations and the conservation of African savanna ecosystems.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses anticipate difficulties accessing the CARES Act loans, which may limit their ability to weather the crisis.

Plastic debris is a growing concern in the ocean, but its magnitude and fate are still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly accumulating in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, with the motorized fleet expanding rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic agent for the treatment of MSA. This study also suggests that VX-765 could be a useful tool to study the mechanisms of α-syn toxicity in synucleinopathies. Finally, this study highlights the potential of VX-765 to be used as a therapeutic agent for the treatment of other neurodegenerative diseases that are characterized by the accumulation of α-syn aggregates.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is a highly specialized cell type that controls vascular function and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are connected by a network of junctions. The endothelium is a complex system that receives and integrates information from multiple sources to control vascular function. This paper describes the nature of the communication network that operates between endothelial cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. The findings reveal that the endothelium is a highly connected network that is particularly efficient in the transmission of information. This network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for the development of therapies to treat cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers in their efforts to understand and respond to the pandemic.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. The activation gate closes the selectivity filter, and the selectivity filter is required for the activation gate to open. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic, with the composition of the microbiome changing in response to diet, stress, and other factors. The gut microbiome is also highly diverse, with many different species of bacteria and fungi inhabiting the digestive tract. The anaerobic fungi that inhabit the digestive tract are poorly characterized, and their potential to produce bioactive compounds has not been investigated. Here, we report the discovery of a diverse set of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi produce natural products and provide a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders

The ability to design and fabricate multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we demonstrate that the IGF2BP1 mRNA-binding protein is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway. We show that IGF2BP1 is developmentally silenced in the fetal liver and that IGF2BP1 overexpression in adult human bone marrow causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This phenotype is associated with reduced BCL11A protein expression and increased fetal hemoglobin levels. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer cells are highly resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is associated with sustained activation of the mTORC1 signaling pathway, which in turn activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. This study demonstrates that targeting mTORC1 sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that SREBP1/SCD1-mediated lipogenesis is a key mechanism of ferroptosis resistance. These findings suggest that mTORC1 inhibition may be combined with ferroptosis induction to treat cancer cells with PI3K or PTEN mutation. This combination therapy may be effective in a wide range of cancers, including those with activating mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. (Show more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure, the leading cause of hospitalization and death in the United States. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, these drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs are more associated with heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs in patients. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study may help to improve the safety of LCCBs. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition, but the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our results show that the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting has not been sufficient to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We conclude that the NWFP needs to be strengthened to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems on federal land may impede the development of older-forest structure. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the solubility, the membrane permeability, and the binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and it was found to be active against antibiotic-resistant strains. The approach presented here can be used to design new antibiotics with improved properties. This work can help to overcome the current antibiotic resistance crisis. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed architecture is a promising alternative to existing architectures for many image-processing problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for researchers and practitioners in the field of image processing.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the YDB cooling.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in autoimmunity and tolerance is still not clear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deficiency leads to lymphoproliferation, autoantibody production, and autoimmunity, but the severity of the diseases is dependent on the time of CTLA-4 deletion.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their extraordinary diversity remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to show that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of plant-feeding beetles, and that the evolution of plant-feeding beetles was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have shown increased transmissibility and immune evasion. To combat the spread of VOCs, we need to develop new therapeutics and vaccines. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our approach can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants, including the Omicron VOCs. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to other protein molecules. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform determines AD risk by ∼12-fold in heterozygotes and by ∼2-fold in homozygotes. APOE is also a potent phagocytic protein that is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we show that APOE isoforms regulate the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which are the major cellular component of senescent synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also show that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in astrocytes, which may accelerate the rate of AD pathogenesis. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the origin of the Earth and the dynamics of the core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, in which the bcc phase of iron nucleates first, followed by the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the Earth. They also suggest that the bcc phase of iron may be more common in the solar system than previously thought. This study may also have implications for the origin of other dense solids in the solar system. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are unknown. We show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This blunted reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain mechanisms underlying it are not well understood. Here, we use a powerful new class of artificial neural networks, “transformers,” to model brain and behavior in language processing. These models outperform previous state-of-the-art models in predicting both neural and behavioral responses to language. We find that the neural correlates of language processing are shaped by the structure of the models, and that model structure strongly predicts the models’ ability to predict behavior. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s computation of language. They also suggest that the transformer architecture may be a promising starting point for future neural network models of language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many fields, but it is still an active area of research. One of the main challenges is that the training of DL models is unstable, even when there are no-free-lunch theorems that guarantee the existence of universal approximators. We show that this instability is not a consequence of the training algorithm but is inherent to the problem. Our results have implications for the design of training algorithms and the study of the stability of neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. The “classic” experiment that is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon was published 45 years ago. It has been cited more than it has been read, and its flaws have been overlooked. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, where leprosy is endemic, and found that it contains a new species, Mycobacterium lepromatosis. This is the first genome sequence of a human pathogen from Latin America. We also found that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of all leprosy bacilli than is M. leprae, suggesting that they have diverged little since their separation. This study provides a phylogeographic survey of M. leprae and M. lepromatosis, and suggests that the two species are still closely related. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of leprosy and the origin of the disease. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the origin of the second law of thermodynamics, respectively. However, the relation between them is still not fully understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems can be completely described in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of quantum many-body systems, including the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our results provide a powerful tool for the study of the relation between entanglement and thermodynamics in general quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vector technology, which have limitations. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is the only vaccine currently in clinical development. The vaccine is temperature sensitive, which allows for large-scale manufacturing. The vaccine is also easy to handle, as it is a live virus. The vaccine is highly attenuated, which results in a milder disease in hamsters. The vaccine is able to protect hamsters from the lethal challenge of the wild-type virus. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This is the first report of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine.

The vector of the disease is still debated, with rodent and human ectoparasite vectors being proposed. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides new insights into the history of plague in Europe. The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is more complex and requires a different approach. We show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is a better predictor of cognitive ability than brain size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, the molecular mechanism by which ADF/cofilin disassembles actin filaments is still unknown. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a molecular explanation for how ADF/cofilin disassembles filaments in a physiological context. They also suggest that ADF/cofilin may be a promising target for therapeutic intervention.

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters because it is calorie-free. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake are unclear. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu populations coexist. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are related, but the Bantu population is admixed with the Asian population. The genomic diversity is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Austronesian and Bantu populations. They also provide a framework for future studies of the genomic diversity of Madagascar. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a critical component of the genetic code that is translated into proteins. The presence of mRNA modifications can have profound effects on mRNA stability, translation, and protein function. In this study, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA can have a modest effect on translation. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a significant impact on the translation of the genetic code. This study provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in the translation of the genetic code. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust across a wide range of sociodemographic factors, and they are also stable over time. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and examination of the fossil record to test the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward a size attractor by the unique energetic demands of the aquatic environment. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward a size attractor by the unique energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

The common cold is a major cause of lost work and school days, and there is no effective vaccine or antiviral treatment. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication suggests that the virus has evolved to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C, which correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings suggest that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Our results provide insight into the molecular basis of rhinovirus temperature dependence and may lead to the development of new antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients and other individuals with compromised immune systems. It is also a leading cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia in intensive care units. The bacterium is able to cause infections in spite of the fact that it lacks a host immune system and has no obvious means to avoid detection and destruction by the host. One of the main virulence factors of P. aeruginosa is the ability to form biofilms, which are dense communities of bacteria embedded in a self-produced polymeric matrix. In this study, we show that P. aeruginosa uses its surface-associated pili to detect surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This is an example of how bacteria can use their appendages for multiple functions, including sensing and signaling. Understanding how bacteria use their appendages for sensing and signaling may help us to develop new strategies to combat infections caused by this and other pathogens.

The presence of pesticides in surface waters is a global concern. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies (>2,500 sites in 73 countries) that evaluates the exposure of surface waters to particularly toxic agricultural insecticides. Our analysis reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and society. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into humans and the possibility of long-term transmission. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 may be circulating in deer and that multiple human-to-deer transmission events have occurred. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a coordinated global effort to monitor and mitigate the impact of the pandemic on wildlife and the environment. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that needs to be addressed. This paper examines the problems associated with the construction of large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still debated. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also burdened with Aβ. We demonstrate that neurons produce a variety of potent immune factors, which are absent from glial cells. Moreover, we identify a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the Aβ peptide in the AD pathogenesis. It also opens up a new avenue for the development of therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. The present study provides evidence that the folding of the large maltose binding protein is a multistep process. The folding is initiated by a fast collapse of the protein into a polyglobular state, which is followed by a slower formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is a prerequisite for the formation of the native state. The intermediate is also a prerequisite for the folding of a large protein, which suggests that the intermediate is a general feature of protein folding. The intermediate is a prerequisite for the folding of a large protein, which suggests that the intermediate is a general feature of protein folding.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and are thought to function as signaling molecules in bacteria. In this study, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by disulfide stress, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such conditions. Unexpectedly, RppH prefers to decape N-glycolylneuraminic acid-capped RNA over its dinucleoside tetraphosphate counterpart, generating a one-nucleotide shift in the 5′ terminus. This shift is required to stimulate rapid RNA degradation by the endoribonuclease DprA. The unconventional manner in which RppH decaps Np4-capped RNA as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of RNA decay and the role of alarmones in bacterial stress response. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We found that citrulline, a dietary amino acid that is converted to arginine in the body, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study could also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for other conditions associated with immune dysfunction. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which the system’s activity is maintained at a constant level with no externally imposed stimulus. SOC systems are characterized by self-similarity, power-law distributions, and absence of long-range correlations. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. It is not ductile. This work shows that diamond can be ductile, and that ductile diamond can be metallized. This is a significant advance in the properties of diamond. It offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also offers opportunities to use diamond as a ductile material in applications where diamond is currently used as a brittle material. This work is expected to advance the properties of diamond and to promote its applications. It is also expected to advance the understanding of the properties of diamond.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the antifungal activity of legume immune peptides has not been studied. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a legume immune peptide, NCR044, against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also report the three-dimensional structure of NCR044 and its mode of action against fungal pathogens. Our work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of legume immune peptides and opens up the possibility of using them as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This could be a useful tool for the sustainable management of plant fungal diseases.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely to be a site of molecular continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We used proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determined the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that female-derived proteins become associated with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular hand-off between males and females.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. In recent years, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has also gained momentum, but the viral component of the microbiome is still largely unknown. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. (Show more)

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred from isotopic evidence, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a ubiquitous ion channel that plays important roles in many physiological processes. It is a unique K+ channel in that it lacks a classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the BK channel’s unique properties. It also provides a possible explanation for the BK channel’s physiological roles and pharmacological targets. It may also help to understand the molecular mechanism of C-type inactivation in other K+ channels. (Show more)

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the human red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. It is not ductile. This work shows that diamond can be ductile, and that ductile diamond can be metallized. This is a significant advance in the properties of diamond. It offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also offers opportunities to use diamond as a ductile material in applications where diamond is currently used as a brittle material. This work opens up new scientific questions and new scientific discoveries. It also offers opportunities to use machine learning to discover new materials and new materials properties.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapeutics. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to unfold sequentially, word by word. However, linguists have long argued that the brain’s underlying syntactic structure is more complex, involving a tree of nested phrases rather than a linear sequence of words. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how the brain builds syntactic structures. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser, which compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions, cell proliferation, and cell survival. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor Frizzled (FZD) and the downstream scaffold Axin. Axin is a large protein that can be regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level to control the amount of Axin available for binding to FZD. This fine-tuning of the pathway is important for tissue-specific regulation of gene expression.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH GABA neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH GABA neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the substantia nigra pars reticulata and locus coeruleus. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural regions. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture has been limited by the need to maintain a close association with the plant, which is difficult to achieve in many crops. Here, we demonstrate a system in which the nitrogen-fixing bacteria are only active when in contact with the host plant, thus avoiding competition with other plants. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of diazotroph gene expression. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of nitrogen fixation in agriculture. It will also have a significant impact on the field of synthetic biology, as it demonstrates the use of a synthetic signal for the control of diazotroph gene expression.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate, and the causes of this deforestation are not well understood. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our results also suggest that the effectiveness of such programs depends on the ability to incentivize community members to patrol forests and that the presence of monitors may inhibit timely detection of and responses to deforestation. Our results have implications for the design of forest monitoring and governance systems in the Amazon and beyond.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize acoustic signals, such as those emitted by prey or predators. The acoustic sensors of animals are constrained by the organism’s body size, and the maximum size of the acoustic sensor is limited by the acoustic efficiency of the sensor. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear by outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its self-manufactured web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect and localize acoustic signals. The spider can increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing in animals and the design of acoustic sensors for future applications. (Show more)

The climate and health impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that aerosols are the dominant cause of aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns and of the warming, and greenhouse gases are the dominant cause of aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns and of the warming. We also show that aerosols and greenhouse gases are the dominant causes of the excess mortality from outdoor air pollution. A rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern has raised concerns about the efficacy of current vaccines. Here we report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be expressed in a robust manner in bacteria, and presentation of the protein on a virus-like particle reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD may be a promising candidate for a future vaccine. This engineered RBD may also be useful for the development of diagnostics and therapeutics. The ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand pair is implicated in the development of several human cancers. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALKALS can activate zebrafish ALK/ALKALS in vivo. Furthermore, we show that zebrafish ALKALS are required for zebrafish iridophore patterning. These results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALS in neural crest development and suggest that ALKALS may be promising therapeutic targets in zebrafish and human neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The pathogen’s origins and early evolution are poorly understood, and the earliest plague genomes are limited to a few samples from the Neolithic period. Here, we present 17 genomes from the Bronze Age, which represents a critical period of development for the pathogen. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This information is critical for understanding the origins of plague and its potential for future outbreaks.

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive emissions of carbon to the atmosphere. However, the potential of alternative management practices to sequester carbon in soils has not been fully explored. We show that the management of cropland with reduced tillage, diverse crop rotations, and livestock integration can increase carbon storage in soils. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and highlight the importance of integrating livestock into crop production systems. Our findings have important implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose a spillover risk to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a visually important trait in plants.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a unique sample of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that men had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that women also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The emergence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) has caused ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how MERS-CoV spreads to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings also provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. (Show more)

The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens has the potential to cause severe epidemics in resource-scarce settings. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including dengue virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and chikungunya virus. Our findings highlight the potential of mNGS to detect undifferentiated febrile illness caused by a diverse range of pathogens in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings.

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The polymerase responsible for this process, DNA polymerase δ (pol δ), is a large enzyme that requires a sliding clamp to replicate the template. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with the sliding clamp while replicating DNA. This behavior has profound implications for Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from the sliding clamp on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the unique properties of lagging strand replication in humans. They also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme may be a target for therapeutic intervention. This may be particularly relevant for cancer cells that rely on the activity of pol δ for replication. Our results also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme may be a target for therapeutic intervention.
