The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA ribozymes, but the replication of RNA by RNA ribozymes has not been demonstrated. Here, we show that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA molecules, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Furthermore, we show that the polymerase can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhoods that are physically close to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of urban change. We hope that our work will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study urban change.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, is a potential therapeutic strategy for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but excess copper is toxic to cells. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to produce antimicrobial xanthocillin analogs, but the BGC has not been shown to bind copper. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC produces xanthocillin analogs that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. We also show that xanthocillin analogs have antimicrobial properties and that copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xanthocillin analogs are conserved in other filamentous fungi. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the impact of copper on fungal interactions with competing microbes. This work also provides a model for the discovery of fungal natural products that bind and impact cellular copper content. This model may be applied to other essential metals. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is consistent with high formation temperatures and suggests that the sediment source region was a high-temperature environment. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment suggests that the sediment was derived from the crater wall/rim/central peak. The amorphous precipitated silica, magnetite, and mixed-cation salts and oxides are products of multiple aqueous infiltrations. The presence of post-lithification anhydrite suggests that the sediment was not deposited in a dry environment.

Frost damage is a major threat to the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance traits to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our results also highlight the importance of studying the evolutionary impact of frost events, which can be different from their ecological impact.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. We show that Th17 cells can directly induce colitis by transitioning to Th1-like cells and that they can support the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have important implications for the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and for the development of therapeutic strategies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is difficult to model in animal models, and there are no effective treatments. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for new treatments. This will greatly facilitate ALS research and the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. We now demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance its colonization. We show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which encodes a protein with several properties, including the ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. IAFGP perturbs the tick gut microbiota, which influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier—critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is a key transition in the origin of flight. The discovery of a basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) adds important information about the origin of the modern avian bauplan. The new taxon, Jinguofortis perplexus, is the second earliest diverging member of the Pygostylia and preserves a mosaic combination of plesiomorphic nonavian theropod features and more derived flight-related morphologies. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand it by looking at individual components. For example, it is difficult to understand the climate system by looking at the temperature changes in the atmosphere. We can understand the climate system by looking at the changes in the atmosphere and the ocean, but this is a difficult task. In this paper, we show that we can understand the climate system by looking at the changes in the atmosphere, the ocean, and the stratosphere.

Vertebrates have evolved a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even to ultraviolet. The presence of these colors is often associated with a particular lifestyle or habitat, but the biochemical basis of color in vertebrates is poorly understood. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is associated with the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in the blood. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. These findings have important implications for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with increased tumorigenesis and metastasis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes breast cancer progression are not well understood. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates NANOG mRNA, a factor that is required for maintenance of pluripotency. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs), and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that exhibit the cancer stem cell phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and this may contribute to the development of breast cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This study reports the results of a noninvasive method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. The results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This study also demonstrates the potential of this method to identify the animal origin of parchment. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter for understanding the causes of the event and its aftermath. The age model for the extinction is based on a new set of U-Pb dates from the Meishan section in China. The dates define an age range of 251.941 ± 0.037 to 251.880 ± 0.031 Ma for the extinction, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization precedes the extinction and persists for ∼500 ka, suggesting that the carbon cycle was a key factor in the demise of Permian life. The dates also provide a precise age for the beginning of the recovery of Permian life. The dates will be useful for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The dates will also be useful for evaluating the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction. The dates will also be useful for evaluating the role of the carbon cycle in the demise of Permian life.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific function of RORα is still unknown. Here, we generated IEC-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses, and it is hypothesized to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the D614 and G614 spike proteins and show that the G614 mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results support the hypothesis that the D614G mutation increases infectivity. (Show more)

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, disproportionately affecting Black and Latino Americans. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. The Black−White life expectancy gap is projected to increase by nearly 40%, and the Latino−White gap is projected to decrease by more than 3 y. These projections have important implications for the future of the US population and for the country’s ability to meet its social and economic goals.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as materials science. In this work, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model. This work opens the door to the study of pressure-induced chemical phenomena, which are of great interest in the scientific community.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions, but the global-scale effects are uncertain. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant drivers of fire activity in the last century, with climate change playing a minor role. However, climate change may have a significant impact in the future, with the potential to reduce global warming. We show that climate change can reduce global warming, but that this effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions and fire suppression in driving fire regimes, and the potential for climate change to reverse this.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided to the squid only at dusk, when the squid’s symbiotic crypts are most metabolically active. We propose that this strategy may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify latent patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of word embeddings to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We model the generative process that generates a sequence of words, and we infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not the consequence of a single introduction, but rather of multiple introductions, each of which was followed by a delay of 15 y before the disease became established in Europe. Asteroids are a common species on the Northeast Pacific Coast. In recent years, populations of at least 20 species have experienced an extensive outbreak of a disease characterized by rapid degradation of tissues. The disease is caused by a densovirus that is transmitted by starfish. The virus is likely to be the cause of the mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of AML stem cells is of great importance for the development of more efficient therapies. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on AML stem cells have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that IL-1 signaling may be important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, blocking IL-1 signaling may be a promising strategy for the treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new approach to study the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a new perspective on the origin of the Malagasy population and the origin of the Austronesian population. It is also a step toward the understanding of the origin of the Bantu population. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings suggest that the dual-function RNA is a complex regulatory element that is likely to have evolved to control carbon utilization. This work provides insight into the evolution of dual-function RNAs

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the need for new therapeutic strategies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the neutralizing activity of an existing antibody, P36-5D2, against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to optimize the antibody sequence to improve its binding affinity to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by improving the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including the Delta variant. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into an antibody drug candidate for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics, to improve their performance against emerging variants. This work highlights the potential of deep learning in accelerating the development of therapeutic strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their data is often not used in agricultural decision-making because it is difficult to integrate into operational systems. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is conducted by the US Department of Agriculture, is a rich source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We show that the CPC can be used to produce a Crop Condition Index that is more accurate than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC can be used to produce more accurate forecasts of crop yields, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This information can be used to improve agricultural decision-making and reduce the risk of crop failures.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. We show that these changes can be used to store information and that they are sensitive to context and serial order. This mechanism is sensitive to the context in which information is stored and can be used to integrate information over time. It is therefore suitable for the binding of linguistic features within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is associated with the loss of photosynthesis and the acquisition of a new lifestyle, which is characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome, which are in turn linked to the parasite’s lifestyle. Our results have implications for the study of the origin of plastids and the evolution of the plastid genome. They also have implications for the study of the origin of life.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa and other water-scarce regions to extreme droughts. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the attribution of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought to anthropogenic climate change. However, the results presented here are limited to the region of southwestern South Africa and cannot be generalized to other regions. Future work

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, was discovered in the red trinitite, the glassy material left over from the first nuclear test explosion. The discovery of this material, which was formed by human hands, has implications for the origin of quasicrystals and for the search for extraterrestrial materials.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity, suggesting that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a critical role in the later stage of EAE, and ASK1 in astrocytes is required for the generation of astrocytic CCL2. These findings provide insights into the roles of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE and suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a multifactorial inheritance pattern. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the converging functions of autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present across cultures and languages. However, individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is also evident, suggesting that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+)$$ _{Ca2+} $$_{Ca2+}$ channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 associated with bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy, and show that these mutations cause constitutive activation of the SOCE channel in vitro and spontaneous bleeding in zebrafish embryos. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SOCE signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SOCE channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the cell membrane, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading of neurodegenerative disease. (Show more)

The identification of the immunologically privileged sites in bats is of great importance for the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent and treat viral infections in humans and animals. Here, we identified a highly concentrated immunologically privileged site in bats, the submandibular salivary gland, and characterized the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in this site. MTX is a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) and is essential for maintaining high stability of host immune responses. MTX is a promising therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we identify a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits plant SHMT, and use this scaffold to discover dual SHMT1/2 inhibitors. We show that these inhibitors are effective in cancer cells, and that formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition. However, formate is toxic to cells, and paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. We show that formate toxicity is rooted in defective glycine import, and that this is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a metabolic deficiency of cancer cells, and may be a targetable metabolic deficiency of other cancers. This study provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as cancer therapeutics. It also provides a foundation for the development of formate-based metabolic inhibitors of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the coaggregating proteins have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a mechanism for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS. It also suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord may be a common feature of various forms of ALS. This may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the photonic crystal system is a promising platform for exploring a wide range of quantum phenomena, including the study of topological photonics, the generation of quantum light, and the control of quantum states of matter. This work opens up a new direction for the study of quantum many-body physics with neutral atoms. The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a better understanding of the origin of the flowering plants. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a living plant that reproduces above the surface of the water. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The rate of global mean sea level rise is one of the most important indicators of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the acceleration of global mean sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the time period for which we have the most precise satellite altimeter data. This acceleration is consistent with the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y estimated by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader trend of decline in the quality of life for those born after 1950.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal of structural biology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of a biologically relevant enzyme intermediate. This approach provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity that is not possible with either NMR or X-ray crystallography alone. This integrated approach offers the promise of mechanistic enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe emerging coronavirus infection that causes a high mortality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the only available treatment is supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there is a pressing need for effective antiviral treatments for these emerging infections. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the stability of their mutualisms. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided to the squid only at dusk, when the squid’s symbiotic crypts are being colonized by the bacteria. We show that the bacteria are required for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which increases the level of oxygen available to the bacteria. This, in turn, enhances the bacteria’s capacity to produce light at night. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their symbionts. This may be particularly important in the case of luminescent symbionts, which are often associated with disease.

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. We tested whether teachers (n = 39) could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline—to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions. Moreover, teachers’ mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. This study has implications for the future of school discipline.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and genomic instability. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages during virus-producing cell secretion. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the world’s population are a key lever for change. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a significant impact on meal selection. This approach could be used to encourage more people to choose vegetarian meals, which have a lower environmental impact and are associated with improved population health. The approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. The results suggest that it is possible to make a significant contribution to environmental sustainability and population health by changing catering practices.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a resource for the breast cancer community and beyond. The data are available at ProteomeXchange with identifier PXD01899. The AI-ETD data are available at ProteomeX

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail programs are unlikely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election. However, our findings do not preclude the possibility that vote-by-mail could have a significant impact in future elections.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostics and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2 is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a. This study provides insight into the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. It also provides a foundation for the development of therapeutics and diagnostics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces EC development from human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-transduced fibroblasts exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that ETV2 provides a useful tool for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This approach may be applicable to the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes and the development of vascular networks for regenerative medicine. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function of these receptors and their ligands. We show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes encoding ligands for Alk and Ltk. We demonstrate that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development and that deficiency in these ligands results in a severe impairment in iridophore patterning. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our findings provide insights into the physiological function of Alk and Ltk and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. STING deficiency in peripheral tissues did not affect glucose homeostasis. These findings suggest that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of viral RNA into virions is a fundamental process in all viruses, but the molecular details of this process are still unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key environmental factor that promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow regulation of vascular phenotypes remain largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow promotes the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow regulation of vascular phenotypes and suggest YAP/TAZ as a therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis. These results may also have implications for the development of other cardiovascular diseases. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been a fundamental part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades. This trend has been driven by humans, not climate change, and is a result of our actions. We provide a quantitative assessment of the role of humans in increasing the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. Our results highlight the importance of human-caused wildfires in driving overall fire risk and call for increased management of human-caused wildfires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the residents who live there. This may have important implications for urban planning and policy.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. We identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study also provides a new target for the development of scorpion-derived natural repellents. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of ZIKV pathogenesis are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV replication in individual infected cells are likely to be important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the within-host dynamics of ZIKV are consistent with the clinical observations of the disease. We also provide estimates of the parameters of the model, which can be used to assess the potential impact of antiviral treatment. Our results suggest that antiviral treatment given prophylactically starting at the time of infection can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss, whereas treatment given at the time of infection can reduce the peak viral load and shorten the time to undetectable viral load. These results highlight the importance of individual variability in the within-host dynamics of viral infections.

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are still poorly understood. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. We show that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in breast cancer cells that are resistant to chemotherapy and that this expression is enhanced by treatment with this therapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, inhibit the metastasis and reengraftment of breast cancer PDXs, and improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer PDXs. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial, with some studies suggesting that the event began as early as ∼20 ka. Here, we show that the start of the deglaciation coincides with the eruption of Mount Takahe, a small volcano in West Antarctica, which produced a series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions that led to stratospheric ozone depletion. The coincidence of the volcanic eruptions with the start of accelerated deglaciation suggests that the volcanic eruptions were the cause of the climate changes. Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, providing food, livelihoods, and recreation to hundreds of millions of people. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the high dependence of poor and undernourished populations on inland fisheries highlights the need to protect these resources from overfishing and degradation. Our data can be used to identify areas where freshwater fisheries are most vulnerable to degradation and to prioritize conservation efforts. This analysis underscores the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein.

However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a previously unknown form of regeneration in the adult Caenorhabditis elegans nervous system that is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is independent of the DLK-1/DLK signaling pathway. This DLK-independent regeneration is linked to a well-characterized form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration and may provide a mechanism for restoring regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genomic stability. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we describe the distribution of these binding sites in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, and show that the distribution of recombination sites is strikingly similar to that in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the ancient mechanisms of recombination initiation are conserved in eukaryotes.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The identification of resting state networks (RSNs) is a key step in understanding the organization of the brain. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Our results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for efficient translation. The existence of 5′ NAD-RNA in bacteria suggests that NAD+ may be an important modification of eukaryotic mRNA. We show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control can prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The long-term follow-up of the DCCT participants, the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study, showed that metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive therapy, is associated with lower glycemia. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the EDIC Study and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The mechanisms underlying the development of alcohol dependence are not fully understood, but it is clear that the brain is involved in the disease. The gut microbiota has been shown to be altered in psychiatric disorders, which suggests the existence of a gut–brain axis. In the present study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation of biodiversity and the management of ecosystems under climate change.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to correspond to different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is still debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. Our data show that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a mental map of the environment, are anatomically distinct from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons in vivo and will be useful for future studies of navigation and neurodegenerative disorders. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene, which is known to be involved in flowering in plants, is also involved in flowering of dodder, a parasitic plant. Dodder is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants. It also provides a new approach to study the evolution of flowering in general. (Show more)

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides a unique view of the dopamine-containing nigral system. It also suggests that the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study is of interest to researchers in neuroscience, neurology, psychiatry, and pharmacology.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN generates electrical activity by integrating signals from voltage-gated ion channels on the cell membrane with signals from internal Ca2+ stores. Stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ signals in SAN cells. Here, we report that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and regulates Ca2+ signals in SANCs by linking Ca2+ stores with the plasma membrane. Our results reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These findings have important implications for understanding the mechanisms of SAN dysfunction in heart failure and atrial fibrillation. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact synergistically in rice defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of inflammatory mediators. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. We show that these changes can be used to store information and that they are sensitive to context and serial order. This mechanism is sensitive to the context in which information is stored and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It may also have implications for other domains of memory and cognition.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical bottleneck for the development of plant-based therapeutics. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNAi to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to internalize into plant cells and deliver the cargo across the cell wall. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up a new avenue for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and provides a platform for the development of plant-based therapeutics.

Nutrient pollution from small tributaries is a growing concern for large freshwater systems, but it has been largely overlooked in the past. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake, but that the remaining 235 tributaries are responsible for the majority of the nutrient loads from small watersheds. These findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, as they are the most important sources of coastal nutrient pollution. Our results also highlight the importance of dissolved inorganic nutrients in driving coastal nutrient loading, which may be more easily managed than organic forms. Our findings have important implications for coastal eutrophication in large lakes and estuaries worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a small initial condition for the universe is required to explain the observed homogeneity and isotropy of the universe. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning problem may have a common origin in the context of chemical networks.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs and may help explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same key synaptic parameters that are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities when these parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are not tolerated in the in silico model of the disease condition.
